Scarring beautie all bewitching,</br>Tell a tale to hurt it selfe,</br>Tels a tale how men are fleeting,</br>All of Love and his power,</br>Tels how womens shewes are pelfe,</br>And their constancies as flowers.

Aie me pretie wanton boy,</br>What a sire did hatch thee forth,</br>To shew thee of the worlds annoy,</br>Ere thou kenn'st anie pleasure:</br>Such a favour's nothing worth,</br>To touch not to taste the treasure.
Poets that divinely dreampt,</br>Telling wonders visedly,</br>My slow Muse have quite benempt,</br>And my rude skonce have aslackt,</br>So I cannot cunningly,</br>Make an image to awake.
Ne the frostie lims of age,</br>Uncouth shape (mickle wonder)</br>To tread with them in equipage,</br>As quaint light blearing eies,</br>Come my pen broken under,</br>Magick-spels such devize.
Collyn was a mighty swaine,</br>In his power all do flourish,</br>We are shepheards but in vaine,</br>There is but one tooke the charge,</br>By his toile we do nourish,</br>And by him are inlarg'd.
He unlockt Albions glorie,</br>He twas tolde of Sidneys honor,</br>Onely he of our stories,</br>Must be sung in greatest pride,</br>In an Eglogue he hath wonne her,</br>Fame and honor on his side.

Deale we not with Rosamond,</br>For the world our sawe will coate,</br>Amintas and Leander's gone,</br>Oh deere sonnes of stately kings,</br>Blessed be your nimble throats,</br>That so amorously could sing.

Adon deafly masking thro,</br>Stately troupes rich conceited,</br>Shew'd he well deserved to,</br>Loves delight on him to gaze,</br>And had not love her selfe intreated,</br>Other nymphs had sent him baies.

Eke in purple roabes distaind,</br>Amid'st the Center of this clime,</br>I have heard saie doth remaine,</br>One whose power floweth far,</br>That should have bene of our rime,</br>The onely object and the star.

Well could his bewitching pen,</br>Done the Muses obiects to us,</br>Although he differs much from men,</br>Tilting under Frieries,</br>Yet his golden art might woo us,</br>To have honored him with baies.
He that gan up to tilt,</br>Babels fresh remembrance,</br>Of the worlds-wracke how twas spilt,</br>And a world of stories made,</br>In a catalogues semblance</br>Hath alike the Muses staide.

What remaines peerelesse men,</br>That in Albions confines are,</br>But eterniz'd with the pen,</br>In sacred Poems and sweet laies,</br>Should be sent to Nations farre,</br>The greatnes of faire Albions praise.

Let them be audacious proude,</br>Whose devises are of currant,</br>Everie stampe is not allow'd,</br>Yet the coine may prove as good,</br>Yourselves know your lines have warrant,</br>I will talke of Robin Hood.

And when all is done and past,</br>Narcissus in another sort,</br>And gaier clothes shall be pla'st,</br>Eke perhaps in good plight,</br>In meane while I'le make report,</br>Of your winnings that do write.

Hence a golden tale might grow,</br>Of due honor and the praise,</br>That longs to Poets, but the show</br>Were not worth the while to spend,</br>Sufficeth that they merit baies,</br>Saie what I can it must have end,</br>Then thus faire Albion flourish so,</br>As Thames may nourish as did Po.</br>
